messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] More on the Akasaka tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Good call Jim, and the conclusion I was going to lead to on the weekend. The tagane in the Tosa Myochin images that you pointed out in the Sasano book has that
messages.messageBody:
Good call Jim, and the conclusion I was going to lead to on the weekend.
The tagane in the Tosa Myochin images that you pointed out in the Sasano
book has that feathered/flared look to it, where as the ones on the last
tsuba I posted and my first one are more like someone's put a chisel
into them to make the fit to the blade more smug (ly). Less style and
more functionality.

An example of 'other' tagane on Tosa Myochin can be seen here
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/toshu-kuniyoshi.jpg

cheers

Rich



Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Akasaka looks like a reasonable call for this, although the poor
> surface condition confuses things.
>
> I think that a lot of the punch marks on the guards being posted are
> things done later in fitting them to blades. Not all Tosa Myochin
> guards show the characteristic kakushi-tagane, but the ones that do
> are distinctive. It's not just any diagonal marking at the top of the
> nakago ana. For examples take a look at numbers 166 and 167 in
> Sasano's "Early Japanese Sword Guards."
>
> Jim
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] More on the Akasaka tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Akasaka looks like a reasonable call for this, although the poor surface condition confuses things. I think that a lot of the punch marks on the guards being
messages.messageBody:
Akasaka looks like a reasonable call for this, although the poor surface condition confuses things.

I think that a lot of the punch marks on the guards being posted are things done later in fitting them to blades. Not all Tosa Myochin guards show the characteristic kakushi-tagane, but the ones that do are distinctive. It's not just any diagonal marking at the top of the nakago ana. For examples take a look at numbers 166 and 167 in Sasano's "Early Japanese Sword Guards."

Jim



All, I am still piecing together some stuff on the Akasaka v Tosa
Myochin punch marks and other possible schools as Jim alluded to but
today I found this on Yahoo Japan.

http://page7.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/jp/auction/g33627227

I would have reservations at calling this Tosa Myochin, but if not
Akasaka, I might go to Higo ?????, which is in the back blocks as a
possibility for my Akasaka piece.

I am still waiting for them to arrive from Japan and still reading and
researching. The other school I found with these whisker like punch
marks is the later Owari works.

Rich Turner


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.messageBody:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: David, The same motif often appears through groups spread around the country.  Since we were talking Akasaka, many of the later Akasaka guards (made in Edo)
messages.messageBody:
David,
The same motif often appears through groups spread around the country. Since we were talking Akasaka, many of the later Akasaka guards (made in Edo) were lifted directly from work originating in Higo (Kyushu). Of course there are also general motifs that persist across long spans of time and space. That's culture.

There are extant pattern books for later iroe shiiremono tsuba. I don't think that I've seen one for sukashi guards, but they might have existed. But, think about our own culture... there are many common and persistent motifs that aren't set forth in a pattern book.

The doubled elements at 12:00 and 6:00 are myoga - ginger shoots. At 3:00 and 9:00 are of course tea whisks. On the diagonals are folding fans and linking them all are birds. The inside of the rim is a very loose kiri. The groups of three dots that you mention as problematic are a standard part of the depiction of myoga in that period.

Jim


It seems odd to me though to think that such explicit copies of so very specific a design, in this case of what seems like less than obvious precise significance (tea whisk + curlew + quadrafoil ?mon? = ???), would be produced by more than one, gegraphically-separated school. Are pattern books of sukashi tsuba known to have existed?

> The edges of the sukashi show some rounding and beveling, where Akasaka is usually quite sharp and vertical. The
> texture of the iron looks a bit softer and grainier than Akasaka. The shape of the design elements is also softer
> and looser than typical for Akasaka, compare the details with the signed example in the Sano catalog. Note also that
> the seppa dai is wider than that one.

I'd certainly love to read more of this sort of exercise in connoisseurship.

BTW, peering at the two, while appreciating Jim Gilbert's analysis, and looking at Ron Hartmann's kakushi-tagane some more, I noticed that both tsubas have a triangular pattern of three dots stamped on the 12 and 6 o'clock dividers around the negative quadrifoil, introducing yet another problematic design element.

David Zincavage

----- Original Message ----- From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 18, 2005 3:54 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba


I also think that it's too old for Tosa Myochin and that the tagane are not as clear as the ones they used. But, to be an even wetter blanket, I'm not convinced that it's Akasaka either. The Akasaka weren't the only group to use this design. The edges of the sukashi show some rounding and beveling, where Akasaka is usually quite sharp and vertical. The texture of the iron looks a bit softer and grainier than Akasaka. The shape of the design elements is also softer and looser than typical for Akasaka, compare the details with the signed example in the Sano catalog. Note also that the seppa dai is wider than that one. Some things to consider.

Jim



Hi Ron, a nice observation. and possibly correct. I went right through
the Akasaka books and cannot find a single tsuba with the kakushi-tagane
though straight lines were used form time to time by the second
Tadamasa. Akasaka and Tosa Myochin can at times be very hard to separate
I find but it is these little tips that help separate them that make the
job just a tad easier.

I guess one thing is, when in hand, it's look of age might help. Sasano
reports that the Tosa Myochin group started in the mid 1800's or there
abouts. I have a signed Tosa Myochin tsuba signed Toshu ju Kuniyoshi
Saku ( shoshin according to Hagihara sensei ) that would date to about
1780 - 1800. I know Cary has a Tosa Myochin piece about the same age. I
have not heard of them earlier than that, has anyone else ?. I kind of
think from the images, this tsuba of mine looks older than the 1800's,
but then again, as I a said, when I have it in hand, it may be easier to
tell.

Anyway, food for thought, I like Tosa Myochin also as a school and would
not be upset if it turned out that way.

best wishes

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, all - Not to be a wet blanket here but--referring to the first tsuba with chidori--I suspect this would be designated Tosa Myochin made in Akasaka
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich, all -

Not to be a wet blanket here but--referring to the first tsuba with chidori--I suspect this would be designated Tosa Myochin made in Akasaka style. I say this because of the distinctive tagane (kakushi-tagane) around the nakago-ana, a Tosa Myochin trait according the Sasano and others. (Sasano points this out in his original English sukashi tsuba book, pages 218-220.)

Not to muddy up the waters, but an odd experience with a like-tsuba was experienced by me back in the early 1980s. In 1979 during a Chicago NTHK shinsa, Sasano papered a friend's mumei tsuba as (I believe) 2nd master Akasaka work. Later, the tsuba went to a Haynes auction where I purchased it. Bob Haynes was adamant about the tsuba "looking like" Akasaka, but that in reality it was Tosa Myochi. His argument was based largely on these "wisker-like" kakushi-tagane that were place around the tsuba's nakago-ana. I sold that tsuba a year or two ago and passed on this story along with the original NTHK paper declaring it Akasaka. Either way, it remains a fine tsuba!

Ron
STL

messages.messageBody:
Found the book. Yep, your tsuba is nearly identical to the one on page 34, except for the different treatment of the left & right side connectors. I think the negative sukashi at 6 and 12 o'clock is called a quatrefoil. I thought I recalled seeing it a book yesterday, but could not remember just where it was. Doesn't seem to be in Dower or Baird.

That's a nice early one you have there, Rich.
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, April 17, 2005 5:21 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba


Hi David, on the left and the right are tea ceremony wisk's ( is that
Karigane ? ) In the Akasaka tsuba book, there are small straight lines
seperating the whisk's from the arc's ( lost for a definition here ) but
they are not chidori ( birds ). Only at 1, 5, 7 and 11 0'clock do you
find the Chidori. If you have the Akasaka book, have a look in there,
this is very close to the design, except for scollaping on the mimi and
some finer detail in the sukashi.

Rich



David Zincavage wrote:

> I wonder if the four chidori/karigane on the left & right may not have
> been modified (deheaded). In fact, I wonder if both hitsu-ana
> altogether may not represent a later modification.
>
> David
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hirata School Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: List- Thanks to all those who replied. Most of the replies were off list. It was a good introduction to Hirata tsuba. The major thing learned by me was to look
messages.messageBody:
List-

Thanks to all those who replied. Most of the replies
were off list. It was a good introduction to Hirata
tsuba.

The major thing learned by me was to look closely at
the fukurin on such tsuba if you don't have then in
hand. The quality of workmanship there can be the most
revealing to those like myself who are newbie to
Hirata tsuba. The fukurin of the tsuba in discussion
seemed to be suspect- but is not a certain thing-,
plus it was discussed that there have been a number of
semi-modern ones floating around within the last year.
In addition, it was discussed that a good number of
convincing "post edo" produced katchushi tsuba have
popped up recently and are being passed off as older
works.

Thanks all for the information.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hirata School Tsuba Question
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, The cloisonné Hirata people worked in Kyoto.  You re talking about Hirata in Higo.  I m not aware of any connection between the groups other than the
messages.messageBody:
Curran,
The cloisonné Hirata people worked in Kyoto. You're talking about Hirata in Higo. I'm not aware of any connection between the groups other than the shared name.

Hirata Hikozo did a lot of work in copper alloys. Most plates are yamagane or copper, but some are shinchu or shakudo. Many of them are lacquered. The mimi edge you're talking about is a fukurin (rim cover) and Hikozo often used them, usually in a contrasting metal. I think that you're describing an Odawara fukurin, which was a particular specialty of Hikozo. Many Hirata guards have the concentric circle file marking you mention, but others have amida yasurime, irregular or polished surfaces. Many do have a distinctive taganemei of heavy, domed punch marks along the sides of the nakago ana.

I can't say what you have without seeing it. There have been contemporary copies of Hikozo's work for sale at US sword shows recently. I don't think that they were made to deceive since they are very obviously brand new, shiny and not at all in the taste of the original time and place. On the other hand, a couple of them turned up at the Chicago shinsa, so someone may have gotten a little confused. I have no idea how the sellers are representing these guards.

Jim



List-

I have recently been looking at a (non cloissone)
Hirata style tsuba:

-It is not iron, but rather seems copper.
-It is plain, unmarked, with the plate being covered
in dark lacquer.
-The mimi edge is done in a sort of silver or other
metal crimped onto the place and fashioned to look
slightly like the edges of an abalone shell or other
mollusk <sorry, I'm not a marine biologist>.

---All in all, sort of a common plain-jane Hirata
style design. The seppa dai area does have those big
pock marks I see on Hirata tsuba.

I am wondering if this is just a very late Hirata, a
Meiji era export, or an attempt to imply Hirata <I had
recently discussed a gi-taganamei Higo Kamiyoshi tsuba
with Jim G., in that the unsigned tsuba had
hammermarks to imply it was the work of second
generation Kamiyoshi "Fukanobu">.
On what little I have seen and very little I know
of such Hirata tsuba, they always have radial marks on
the plate to add to the design impression of a shell.
This one been flat and black lacquered, seems very
odd.

Thank you in advance to any replies,

Curran

messages.messageBody:
List-

I have recently been looking at a (non cloissone)
Hirata style tsuba:

-It is not iron, but rather seems copper.
-It is plain, unmarked, with the plate being covered
in dark lacquer.
-The mimi edge is done in a sort of silver or other
metal crimped onto the place and fashioned to look
slightly like the edges of an abalone shell or other
mollusk <sorry, I'm not a marine biologist>.

---All in all, sort of a common plain-jane Hirata
style design. The seppa dai area does have those big
pock marks I see on Hirata tsuba.

I am wondering if this is just a very late Hirata, a
Meiji era export, or an attempt to imply Hirata <I had
recently discussed a gi-taganamei Higo Kamiyoshi tsuba
with Jim G., in that the unsigned tsuba had
hammermarks to imply it was the work of second
generation Kamiyoshi "Fukanobu">.
On what little I have seen and very little I know
of such Hirata tsuba, they always have radial marks on
the plate to add to the design impression of a shell.
This one been flat and black lacquered, seems very
odd.

Thank you in advance to any replies,

Curran
